tspan.tspan: EMIC-Induced Precipitation as Measured by ELFIN: Source
Julia Claxton (she/her), Robert Marshall – University of Colorado Boulder,
Electromagnetic Ion-Cyclotron (EMIC) waves are thought to be a primary
driver of relativistic electron loss from the outer radiation belt (Ni 2015,
atmospheric impact of this high-energy precipitation is
characterized due to a lack of measurements resolving the loss
Further, the minimum electron energy required for scattering by
used to analyze wave-particle interactions underestimates scattering of
toward an understanding of global EIP fluxes and the energy-domain
response of electrons to EMIC waves by using recent data that can resolve
the interior of the loss cone at a variety of energies.
Candidate EIP events detected using a scoring algorithm. Process: Look
heatmap (see Fig. 1). For high- (> 500 keV) and low- (<500
This produces a precipitation score for low and high energy channels. The
low energy score is then set to its highest value in the surrounding 4
timesteps on either side to reject detections due to the electron isotropy
boundary. A candidate EIP event is returned when:
• Improve algorithm to accept EIP with low-energy precipitation
• Reduce need for human verification of EIP detection
• Expand dataset to capture majority of EIP measured by ELFIN
All code used in this analysis is available at

text.tspan: Fig. 1: ELFIN data showing EIP at ~07:05:00 UTC

tspan.tspan: • EIP events can be detected in particle data by looking for patterns of
• EIP identification does not require conjunctions with other instruments
• EMIC-induced precipitation originates from dusk to nightside at L ≈
• In this set of events, EMIC scattering begins at ~400 keV
• An in-progress EIP detection algorithm is used to
create a set of 237 likely EIP events
• These events primarly originate from dusk to midnight
at L ≈ 5-10, in line with previous results
• EIP precipitation is strongest at ~MeV energies,
extending down to 100s of keV in some cases

text.tspan: Fig. 3: EIP detection rate shown in
MLT/L and a polar projection of
of H-band EMIC waves found in Min
et al. 2012 and Usanova et al. 2012.
Fig. 4: Global atmospheric energy input due to EIP events analyzed,
normalized to the time ELFIN spent in each MLT/latitude bin.
Fig. 6: Quantiles of Jprec/Jtrap distribution for each of ELFIN's energy
channels. Precipitating flux increases with increasing energy, beginning
Fig. 4: Average flux of EIP events, normalized to perpendicular flux, in
pitch angle-energy space. This demonstrates a filling of the loss cone at
high energies, with filling intensity decreasing with energy down to ~200
keV. Atmospheric backscatter can bee seen at ~400 keV in the anti loss

tspan.tspan: • EIP selection punishes low-energy precipitation, potentially excluding
• Varying loss cone coverage requires extrapolation, leading to some
Loss cone must be filled at high energies.
High energy precipitation must be comparable or larger than low
Reject events with very strong low-energy precipitation, e.g. the
G. Van Rossum+ 1995, Python reference manual.
